channel.title: Worldbuilding on Pandaqi Tutorials
channel.description: Recent content in Worldbuilding on Pandaqi Tutorials

item.title: Introduction
item.description: Welcome to the course on Worldbuilding! At first, I wanted to call this one Setting. It’s the more generally applicable term for, well, the setting in which a story takes place.

item.title: What is worldbuilding?
item.description: Before we can talk about worldbuilding, I need to define what it is. To make sure we’re on the same page and you know what you will learn.

item.title: The Purpose of Worldbuilding
item.description: As usual, I also want to devote a chapter on the why question. Why do we need worldbuilding? Why would people like to learn facts about a non-existing world?

item.title: Tip of the Iceberg
item.description: Worlds are big, complicated, messy things with an infinite amount of detail. A common mistake for beginning writers is that they try to put all of that into the story.

item.title: Communicating your Setting I
item.description: This is the trick that writers need to learn, especially fantasy writers. How do you convey information about your world in a natural way?

item.title: Communicating your Setting II
item.description: Previous chapter gave you an idea of the general things to communicate and how to do it. But when is the right time?

item.title: Deep over Shallow
item.description: This is the last chapter before I dive deeper into the four steps of my process (and eventually magic systems).

item.title: Step 1: Pick a Twist
item.description: So you want to write a new story and need to invent an exciting world in which it takes place.

item.title: Step 2: Figure out Basic Needs
item.description: I’ve seen and heard a lot of critical story analyses. A very common critique is that the story was “nonsensical”.

item.title: Step 3: Think of the Implications
item.description: In the first step, you established your core ideas for the setting. In the second step, you considered how (basic) needs would be met in this setting.

item.title: Step 4: Finishing Touches
item.description: You have done the first three steps. You’ve figured out the basic ideas your invented world needs to function and ironed out any contradicting consequences.

item.title: Magic Systems I
item.description: Magic has always been interesting to me. On the one end, the whole draw of magic is that it can’t be explained.

item.title: Magic Systems II
item.description: The previous chapter gave a general overview of magic systems. The different terminology and things to watch out for.

item.title: Conclusion
item.description: Congratulations! You’ve finished the course on Worldbuilding (in Creative Writing). It’s much shorter than other writing courses, but still a lot of information to take in.
